seg.output: This entire letter is addressed to Domino Leoni Iudae, pastor of Sanpetrinae Church, from H. Bullingerus. Greetings. This entire letter revolves around the idea that no matter what kind of magistrate, nothing should be committed concerning ecclesiastical matters. You add the reason, “For magistrates and the church are two very different things; the former rules over things and bodies, the latter over souls.” We are dealing with a slippery matter if anyone would rather force the issue than accept the most simple solution without a curious mind, since nothing said in contentiousness can be said without affording some opportunity for criticism, and since words can be used in many different ways. This has always been a very fertile ground for great disputes among even the greatest men. I do not see how the proposition, “magistrates and the church are two very different things” can be true universally. For if you bring in the magistrates of Pilate, Caiaphas, and Herod, and the synagogue of the Jews, you have brought in tyrants, not magistrates. An impious magistrate is a maimed and crippled magistrate.

seg.output: The whole of this letter, learned Leo, is concerned with the fact that no ecclesiastical matter should be entrusted to any magistrate, whatever kind he may be. You add the reason: "For the magistrate and the Church are very different things; the one has power over bodies, the other over souls." And indeed we are in a slippery business, if any one prefers to strive with might rather than to take up in a simple-minded way the simplest of tasks, since, not only is there nothing so well said that it does not bring with it some ground of criticism, but each word can be used in various ways. This has always been the fruitful source of greatest disputes, even among the greatest men. For my part, I cannot see how this proposition ("the magistrate and the Church are different things") can be universally true. For if you bring forward the magistrates of Pilate, Caiaphas, Herod, and the Jewish synagogues, you have brought tyrants, not magistrates. An impious magistrate is a maimed and crippled magistrate. 1. But if you value the magistrate not so much from his office as from those who fill it, if two or three agree on earth, even if they hold the office of magistrate, they certainly constitute a church, if we believe in Christ. Again, if to hold the office of magistrate is to be a minister of God, if a Christian can be a minister of God, which we have established against the Anabaptists, 2. then, though heathens can in some way be ministers of God, like Nebuchadnezzar and Sennacherib, yet no one knows how to minister to God better than a Christian. You add the reason: "For magistrates and churches are very different things; the one has power over things and bodies, the other over souls." For I cannot see how the proposition (that magistrates and churches are very different things) can be universally true. For if you bring forward Pilate, Caiaphas, Herod, and the Jewish synagogue as magistrates, you have brought tyrants, not magistrates. An impious magistrate is a defective and maimed magistrate. 1. If you estimate the magistrate not so much from his office as from those who exercise it, now if two or three agree on earth, although they exercise the office of magistrate, they certainly constitute a church, if we believe in Christ. Again, if to exercise the office of magistrate is to be a minister of God, and if a Christian can be a minister of God, which we have obtained against the Anabaptists, 2. although heathens in some way can be ministers of God, like Nebuchadnezzar and Sennacherib, yet no one knows better how to minister to God than a Christian. 3. The church of Christians also is a collection. Now I do not see what your words mean: "Magistrates and churches are very different things. Nothing of a religious nature should be committed to whichever kind of magistrate." 4. If you also consider the office of magistrate, and refer it to the separation of church and magistrate, now Paul says: "Rulers are not a terror to the good works, but to the evil." Also: "He is the minister of God, a revenger to execute wrath upon him that doeth evil."

seg.output: The whole of this letter, most learned Leo, is concerned with the fact that nothing relating to the Church should be entrusted to whatever kind of magistrate. seg.output: The whole of this letter, Leo most learned, is concerned with the fact that nothing ecclesiastical should be committed to any magistrate, whatever he may be. You add the reason: "For magistrates and the Church are things of quite different nature: the one has authority over things and bodies, the other over souls." And truly we are dealing with a slippery matter, if any one would rather strive with might than take up the simplest business without a curious mind, since of things controverted there is nothing so well said but it may give occasion of blame, and since single words may be used in different senses. Which has been a fruitful source of the greatest contentions, even among the greatest men. For I see not how this proposition (that magistrates and the Church are things of quite different nature) can be universally true. For if thou bringest in the magistrates of Pilate, of Caiaphas, of Herod, and of the Jewish synagogue, thou hast brought in tyrants and not magistrates. An impious magistrate is a maimed and a mutilated magistrate. But if thou lookest to the magistrate, not so much according to his office, as according to them that bear the office, why, if two or three agree upon earth, although they bear the office of a magistrate, yet, if we believe in Christ, they do constitute a Church. Again, if to bear the office of a magistrate be to be a minister of God, and if a Christian may be a minister of God, which we have obtained against the Anabaptists, why, although the Heathens may in some sort be ministers of God, as Nebuchadnezzar and Sennacherib, yet no man can more rightly minister unto God than a Christian. The Church, moreover, of the Christians is a collective body.

seg.output: In this whole letter, Leo, most learned, the point is that nothing concerning ecclesiastical matters should be committed to any magistrate, whatever kind of one he may be. You add the reason: “For magistrates and the Church are two very different things; the one is over bodies, and the other is over souls.” And certainly we are managing a slippery business, if any one prefers to strive with force rather than to take up without curiosity the simplest of tasks; since nothing can be so well said by contentious persons which does not bring with it the occasion of being blamed, and since single words can be used in various senses. This has been a most fruitful source of the greatest contentions, even among the greatest men. For I do not see how this proposition (“magistrates and the Church are two very different things”) can be universally true. For if you bring in the magistrates of Pilate, of Caiaphas, of Herod, and of the Jewish synagogue, you have brought in tyrants, not magistrates. An impious magistrate is a lame and maimed magistrate. 1. But if you look not so much at the function of the magistrate as at those who bear the office, if two or three agree together on earth, though they bear the office of magistrates, yet if we believe Christ, they do constitute the Church. Again, if to bear the office of a magistrate is to be a minister of God, and if a Christian can be a minister of God, which we have maintained against the Anabaptists, 2. though the heathen may in some way be ministers of God, as Nebuchadnezzar and Sennacherib, yet none can minister to God better than a Christian. 3. The Church of Christians is also a collection. Now I do not see what your words mean: “Magistrates and the Church are two very different things; nothing concerning ecclesiastical matters should be committed to any magistrate, whatever kind of one he may be.” 4. But if you look also at the function of the magistrate, and refer it to the separation of the Church and the magistrate, then Paul: “The rulers,” says he, “are not a terror to the good work, but to the evil”; again: “He is the minister of God, a revenger to execute wrath upon him that doeth evil” [Rom. 13:3f.]. And nowhere more exactly will you find the difference between good and evil than in the Church, which is governed by the word of truth. And the Gentiles and unbelievers are a terror to the good, but Christians are a terror to the evil.

seg.output: This whole letter, O most learned Leo, revolves around this, that no ecclesiastical matters should be committed to the magistrate, whatever it may be. You add the reason: "For the magistrate and the Church are things of the most diverse nature: the one has to do with bodies, the other with souls." And indeed we are managing a slippery matter, if any man choose rather to contend in power than to take up the most simple business with an uninquisitive mind, when, not only nothing can be so well said that it will not bring with it some occasion for censure from the contentious, but also, that single words may be used in different senses. This has always been a very fruitful source of great contentions, even among the most learned. For, I see not how this proposition ("the magistrate and the Church are things of the most diverse nature") can be universally true. For, if you bring in the magistrates of Pilate, Caiaphas, Herod, and the Jewish synagogue, you have brought in tyrants, not magistrates. An impious magistrate is a lame and maimed magistrate.1. But if you take the magistrate not from his function but from those who bear the office, now if two or three agree in the earth, though they bear the office of a magistrate, yet if we believe in Christ, they constitute a Church. Again, if to be a magistrate is to be a minister of God, and if a Christian can be a minister of God, which we have obtained against the Anabaptists,2. now though heathens in some sort may be ministers of God, as Nebuchadnezzar and Sennacherib, yet none can know to minister to God so well as a Christian.3. Again, the Church of Christians is a gathered body. I see not now what your words mean: "The magistrate and the Church are things of the most diverse nature. No ecclesiastical matters should be committed to the magistrate, whatever it may be."4. But if you look also to the function of the magistrate and refer it to the separation of the Church and the magistrate, Paul says, "The higher powers are not a terror to the good works, but to the evil." And again, "He is the minister of God, a revenger to execute wrath upon him that does evil." [Rom 13:3f] And nowhere more exactly is the distinction of good and evil to be found than in the Church, which is ruled by the word of truth. And heathens and unbelievers are a terror to the good, but Christians to the evil.5. And the Holy Ghost speaking of the choosing of a magistrate says, "Provide out of all the people able men, such as fear God, in whom is truth, and that hate covetousness, and place such over them, to be rulers of thousands, rulers of hundreds, rulers of fifties, and rulers of tens" [Ex 18:21f]. This is a rule truly and indeed to those that bear the office of a magistrate. But who would not commit the holy matters of the Church to wise, strong, and God-fearing men?

This whole letter revolves around Leo, the most learned, so that nothing ecclesiastical may be entrusted to any magistracy, whatever it may be. You add the reason: "For magistracy and church are very different things; the one has to do with bodies, the other with souls". 3. The church of Christians is also a collection. Now I do not understand your words: "Magistracy and church are very different things. Nothing of a ecclesiastical nature should be entrusted to the magistracy, whatever it may be."
4. But if you also consider the function of magistracy and refer it to the separation of church and magistracy, then Paul says: "Rulers are not a terror to good works, but to the evil" [Romans 13:3f]. Verum non video, utrum magistratui sint potestates illae delegatae.
In this letter, Leo, most learned, the whole point is that nothing pertaining to the church should be entrusted to any magistrate, whatever his character. You add the reason: "For magistrates and the church are very different institutions. The former has authority over bodies, the latter over souls." And indeed we are handling a slippery business if anyone prefers to wrestle with the matter with force rather than to accept the simplest solution with an uncomplicated mind, seeing that nothing can be said with certainty in contentious matters that does not carry with it some ground for criticism, and that every word can be interpreted in a variety of ways. For that has always been the most fruitful source of disputes even among the greatest of men. For I do not see how your proposition "magistrates and the church are very different institutions" can be universally true. If you bring in the magistrates of Pilate, Caiaphas, Herod and the Jewish synagogue, you have introduced tyrants, not magistrates. An impious magistrate is an incomplete and crippled magistrate.
1. But if you appraise magistrates not in terms of their office but in terms of those who hold office– now if two or three agree on earth, although they hold office, they certainly constitute a church, if we believe in Christ. Again, if to hold office is to be a minister of God, and if a Christian can be a minister of God, which we have established against the Anabaptists,
2. then although the heathen in some way can be ministers of God, like Nebuchadnezzar and Sennacherib, yet none can serve God better than a Christian.
3. Also, the church of Christians is a congregation. Now I do not understand your words: "Magistrates and the church are very different institutions. Nothing pertaining to the church should be entrusted to any magistrate, whatever his character."
4. But if you also consider the office of magistrate and refer it to the separation of the church and the magistrate, then Paul says: "Rulers are not a terror to good works, but to the evil" [Rom 13,3f]. And also: "He is the minister of God to thee for good. But if thou do that which is evil, be afraid; for he beareth not the sword in vain" [Rom 13,4]. And nowhere is the distinction between good and evil more exact than in the church, which is guided by the word of truth. And the heathen and unbelievers are a terror to the good, but to the evil-doers the Christians are a terror.
5. And the Holy Spirit about the election of magistrates: "Provide out of all the people able men, such as fear God, in whom there is truth, and that hate covetousness; and place such over them, to be rulers of thousands, and rulers of hundreds" [Ex 18,21f]. This is the rule for those who hold office, and truly hold office. But who would not commit the sacred affairs of the church to prudent, valiant and God-fearing men? Therefore again I do not understand your proposition: "Nothing pertaining to the church should be entrusted to any magistrate, whatever his character", and also "Magistrates and the church are very different institutions."
6. Moreover, I do not know if any magistrate has been set over souls in the church. I do not deny that the apostles and their successors have been given the power of binding and loosing. But I do not see if those powers have been delegated to the magistrates.

In hoc tota versatur epistola, Leo doctissime, ut magistratui, qualiscunque tandem sit, non committatur quicquam ecclesiasticarum rerum.Addis causam: «Magistratus enim et ecclesia res sunt diversissimae.Alterum enim super res est et corpora, alterum super animas.»Et sane lubricum agimus negotium, si quisquam viribus contendere malit quam simplicissimum negotium non curiosa suscipere mente, cum, quod contentiosis nihil tam bene dici possit, quod non aliquam secum afferat reprehendendi ansam, tum, quod singula verba aliter ac aliter usurpari possunt.Quod equidem maximarum contentionum semper fuit inter summos etiam viros feracissimum seminarium.Ego enim hanc propositionem («magistratus et ecclesia sunt res diversissimae») non video quomodo universaliter possit esse vera.Si enim Pilati, Caiaphae, Herodis et Iudaicae synagogae magistratum adferas, iam tyrannos, non magistratus attulisti.Impius magistratus mancus et mutilus est magistratus.1. Quod si tu magistratum non tam ex functione aestimes quam ex iis, qui gerunt magistratum, iam si duo aut tres consentiant super terram, etsi magistratum gerant, certe ecclesiam, si Christo credimus, constituunt.Rursus, si magistratum gerere est ministrum dei esse, si christianus potest minister dei esse, id quod adversus catabaptistas obtinuimus, 2. iam etsi ethnici aliquo modo possint ministri dei esse veluti Nebuch[adonosor] et Sanherib, nemo tamen melius norit deo ministrare quam christianus.3. Ecclesia item christianorum sit collectio.Iam non video, quid sibi velint ista tua verba: «Magistratus et ecclesia sunt res diversissimae.Nihil ecclesiasticarum rerum committatur magistratui, qualiscunque tandem sit.»4. Quod si functionem quoque magistratus spectas eamque ad separationem ecclesiae et magistratus referas, iam Paulus: «Principes», inquit, «non terrori sunt bene agentibus, sed male».Item: «Dei minister est, ultor ad iram ei, qui, quod malum est, fecerit» [Röm 13,3f].Atque nullibi exactius invenias discrimen boni et mali quam in ecclesia, quae verbo veritatis regitur.Et gentes incredulique bene agentibus terrori sunt, christiani vero male agentibus terrori sunt.5. Et spiritus sanctus de magistratu eligendo: «Provide», inquit, «de omni plebe viros fortes, timentes deum, in quibus sit veritas et qui oderint avaritiam, et ex iis constitue senatores, qui iudicent populum omni tempore» [Ex 18,21f].Haec magistratum gerentibus vereque gerentibus regula.Sed quis non commiserit viris prudentibus, fortibus et deum timentibus res ecclesiae sanctas?Proinde iterum non video, quomodo constet ista tua propositio: «Magistratui, qualiscunque tandem sit, non committatur quicquam rerum ecclesiasticarum», item illa: «Magistratus et ecclesia res sunt diversissimae».6. Deinde nescio, si aliquis magistratus in ecclesia super animas sit constitutus.Non nego ligandi et solvendi potestatem datam esse apostolis et successoribus.Sed Zuinglio praeceptore didicimus clavium potestatem evangelii esse praedicationem, quae aliis mortem minatur, aliis pollicetur vitam.

seg.output: In this letter, Leo, most learned, the whole point revolves around not committing anything of an ecclesiastical nature to any magistrate, whatever kind it may be.You add the reason: "For magistrates and the church are two very different things; the former is over things and bodies, the latter over souls."And indeed we undertake a slippery task, if anyone would rather fight with might than take up a simple matter with an uncomplicated mind, since not only is nothing so well said that it cannot bring with it some occasion of blame, but also because single words can be used in different ways.This has always been the most fruitful source of the greatest disputes, even among the most learned men.For I do not see how this proposition (that "magistrates and the church are two very different things") can be universally true.For if you bring Pilate, Caiaphas, Herod and the Jewish synagogue as magistrates, you have already brought tyrants, not magistrates.An impious magistrate is a crippled and mutilated magistrate.1. But if you consider the magistrate not so much from the function as from those who exercise it, now if two or three agree on earth, although they exercise the magistrate, they certainly constitute the church, if we believe in Christ.Again, if it is to be a minister of God to exercise the magistrate, if a Christian can be a minister of God, which we have maintained against the Anabaptists,2. then although the Gentiles in some way can be ministers of God, such as Nebuchadnezzar and Sanherib, yet no one knows better how to minister to God than a Christian.3. Also, the church of Christians is a collection.Now I do not see what your words mean: "Magistrates and the church are two very different things; nothing of an ecclesiastical nature should be committed to any magistrate, whatever kind it may be."4. But if you also consider the function of the magistrate and refer it to the separation of the church and the magistrate, then Paul says: "Rulers are not a terror to the good works, but to the evil" [Rom 13:3f].Also: "He is a minister of God, a revenger to execute wrath upon him that does evil" [Rom 13:4].And nowhere will you find a better distinction between good and evil than in the church, which is governed by the word of truth.And the Gentiles and the unbelievers are a terror to the good works, but the Christians are a terror to the evil works.5. Also, the Holy Spirit about electing a magistrate: "Provide," he says, "out of all the people able men, such as fear God, in whom is truth and who hate covetousness, and set them to rule over the people at all times" [Ex 18:21f].This is a true and proper rule for those who exercise the magistrate.But who would not commit the holy things of the church to prudent, strong and God-fearing men?Therefore again I do not see how your proposition stands: "Nothing of an ecclesiastical nature shall be committed to any magistrate, whatever kind it may be," and also this: "Magistrates and the church are two very different things."6. Moreover, I do not know if any magistrate is set over souls in the church.I do not deny that the power of binding and loosing was given to the apostles and their successors.But we have learned from Zuinglio, our teacher, that the power of the keys is the preaching of the gospel, which threatens death to some and promises life to others.As for excommunication, which perhaps might appear to be imposed by spiritual authority over souls, it is certain that the sin of a man is forgiven when he returns to the Lord by faith.As for excommunication, which perhaps might appear to be imposed by spiritual authority over souls, it is certain that the sin of a man is forgiven when he returns to the Lord by faith.Witnesses stand the prodigal son, the publican, Peter and the thief etc.As for excommunication, which perhaps might appear to be imposed by spiritual authority over souls, it is certain that the sin of a man is forgiven when he returns to the Lord by faith.Witnesses stand the prodigal son, the publican, Peter and the thief etc.From which it follows that excommunication is not an internal and spiritual punishment of the soul, but an external penalty inflicted because of scandal.As for excommunication, which perhaps might appear to be imposed by spiritual authority over souls, it is certain that the sin of a man is forgiven when he returns to the Lord by faith.Witnesses stand the prodigal son, the publican, Peter and the thief etc.From which it follows that excommunication is not an internal and spiritual punishment of the soul, but an external penalty inflicted because of scandal.Which Paul also expressed most significantly when he spoke of the fornicator, saying: "Deliver him unto Satan for the destruction of the flesh" [1 Cor 5:5].

seg.output: As far as excommunication is concerned, which may have seemed imposed on souls by spiritual authority, it is certain that sin is forgiven to a man when he returns to the Lord through faith. Witnesses stand the prodigal son, the publican, Peter and the thief, etc. It follows that excommunication is not an internal punishment for the soul, but an external penalty imposed due to scandal. This is what Paul expressed very significantly when he said about the adulterer: “Let him be handed over to Satan for the destruction of the flesh” [1 Corinthians 5:5]. What else does it mean to hand over to Satan than to throw into adversity and afflict? This is how Job was also handed over to Satan. What else is the destruction of the flesh than an external penalty or repression, punishment or mortification of the flesh? Whether it is done through contempt, neglect or any other way, provided it is done and public decency is defended. Moreover, in 2 Corinthians 2 [6] he wrote the same thing: “This punishment is sufficient for such a man”, that is, a penalty and correction. Consult G. Budaeus on the force of the words Τιμάν and ΤιμάσΒαι and the clearest light will come.

seg.output: I do not contend that this duty should be assigned only to the magistrate, or that it should be committed to no one but him, nor did I intend to assert this in my previous letter to Berchtold; but I argued against the Anabaptists who attribute this to the general populace and to their own faction, which they call the Church, so that yours would not have been necessary. For after a great deal of discussion, you eventually come to the conclusion that the Church's excommunication is to be the responsibility of the elders to whom the Church has been entrusted. I also say and believe this, and I draw the conclusion from this that if it is to be entrusted to the magistrate, excommunication, that is, the public punishment of public crimes, is already present with him. But here you think that the magistrate must never be allowed to do anything, whatever it is. Of this matter previously. For it is wicked, you say, for the magistrate to do this. Was it then any better, or any other than it is now, when it was committed to the diocesans and judges of matrimonial cases? But it was much worse then. The state of affairs will never return, so that the Church, which we can more truly imagine than see, is composed of prefects, such as we wish or desire to be holy, pure, and perfect in all respects. This has been proved to us before in the two highest orders of the Church. For among the very few apostles, a traitor was found, and among the seven deacons, Nicholas the heretic. But the rest were not to be immediately blamed or deprived of their office on the name of some.

seg.output: It will never happen again that our church would be led by such prefects as we desire or wish for, holy, unpolluted and blessed in every way, as we can better imagine than see. This had already been proven to us in two of the Church's greatest orders. For among the very few apostles there was a betrayer, and among the seven deacons Nicholas was a heretic. But the rest were not immediately to be despised by any name or deprived of their office. In the end it is one thing to be bound by the suffrages of the wicked, and another thing to be under laws, even if they are wicked. Among the nations usury, fornication, drunkenness and so on were not punished by every magistrate, nor had every magistrate prohibited them. But with us these are so joined to the civic laws, as being in a Christian state, that, even though some wicked persons may plead for them, yet they are liable to the penalty of violated laws, and the just cannot by any equity be compelled to their opinion. For the public edict and public constitution perpetually stand in the way, by which even the good and the bishops may be pressed. Add to this that we shall not have avoided this danger, if we take away the punishment of crimes from the magistrate and commit them to certain men of the Church, as if, to be sure, those men could not be Ananias, Demas, and many others of the like.

Ad haec nostra opportune accommodanda sunt, ut non solum liberum iudicium, sed etiam prudentia, consilium, auctoritas, consensio et consuetudo, quae omnia in ecclesia, cum recte instituuntur, laus dignissima sunt.
Now our state will never return to what we can imagine rather than see, with such rulers as we want or wish, holy, spotless and blessed in every way.This was once proven to us in the two greatest orders of the Church.For among the very few apostles was found a betrayer, and among the seven deacons, Nicholas, a heretic.But the rest were not immediately to be despised by some name or deprived of their office.For it is one thing when we are bound by the suffrages of the wicked, and another when even the wicked are subject to laws.Among the nations, usury, fornication, drunkenness, etc. were not punished by all magistrates, nor had any magistrate proscribed these things.But among us these are so interwoven with civil laws, as being in a Christian state, that if a few wicked persons should complain, yet those who are more righteous cannot with any equity be forced to their opinion.For a public edict, a public constitution, is ever opposed to it, by which even the good and the bishops may now be urged.To which add, that we should not have avoided this danger, though we had taken away the punishment due to wickedness, and had assigned certain persons to the Church, as if those men could not be and could not express the example of Ananias, Demas, and many others.For it was not in vain that the illustrious man Zuinglius wrote against the Anabaptists, that our calamity is so great, that we have not yet found among men a perfectness so absolute, nor is it to be expected that all who confess Christ shall all be blessed in every way, so long as this house of the body is carried about.
Therefore, since we must act as we can (unless we choose to mingle all things in confusion), when it is not lawful as we would have it, I chiefly direct my thoughts this way, that we may have a peaceful Church, and one not altogether impudently offending; a peaceful one indeed, not without tribulations - for all those who will live piously in Christ must needs be afflicted - but peaceful as to those who are in the Church; and not altogether impudently offending.For we are men, as long as we live; therefore nothing of the human is to be alien to us.Therefore, since we must act as we can (unless we choose to mingle all things in confusion), when it is not lawful as we would have it, I chiefly direct my thoughts this way, that we may have a peaceful Church, and one not altogether impudently offending; a peaceful one indeed, not without tribulations - for all those who will live piously in Christ must needs be afflicted - but peaceful as to those who are in the Church; and not altogether impudently offending.For the wisest are often seduced by sins, and the best are often wanting, but they return in due time.Therefore, since we must act as we can (unless we choose to mingle all things in confusion), when it is not lawful as we would have it, I chiefly direct my thoughts this way, that we may have a peaceful Church, and one not altogether impudently offending; a peaceful one indeed, not without tribulations - for all those who will live piously in Christ must needs be afflicted - but peaceful as to those who are in the Church; and not altogether impudently offending.For the wisest are often seduced by sins, and the best are often wanting, but they return in due time.Wherefore need I say more? To these things our affairs are fitly to be accommodated, that we may have not only a free judgment, but also prudence, counsel, authority, consent, and custom, which all, when rightly exercised in the Church, are very worthy of praise.

seg.output:
Therefore, since we must act as best we can (unless we choose to mix up all the chaos), when we cannot do as we wish, I am focusing solely on this point: that we have a peaceful church and one that is not altogether impudently sinning, certainly not without tribulations - for it is necessary that all who wish to live piously in Christ be afflicted - but a peaceful church insofar as it concerns those who are in the church; and one that is not altogether impudently sinning. For we are men so long as we live; thus, nothing human will be alien to us. Even the best are often led astray by sin, and the most brilliant fail; but they eventually return in due time. Why say more? We are men. Furthermore, we are discussing the external church, not the internal one, which, after charity, has no need of laws, but does, however, enjoy public edicts, as if to oppose evil with affliction. The good detest sinning out of love of virtue, and the wicked out of fear of punishment. The pious do what is just out of the love of justice, and the impious have a law set before them. In the external church then, as Christ painted in Matthew 13 [24ff], there is need of punishment, which is excommunication. In this severity of the shepherds, they must be restrained.
Why say more? I can entrust the authority of excommunication to certain men, if, by doing so, we bring glory to God or if we make something better through this innovation or if, by this means, we are able to more strongly oppose the wicked and their impiety than we have been able to do so far. seg.output: What then is the need of many? I too can entrust the authority of excommunication to certain persons, provided that this course of action would bring glory to our city or that we might do better something with this innovation, or that we might be able to more strongly resist the ungodly and impiety than we have done up to this point. For all things must be done by us for edification and done cautiously, lest we bring the church to the utmost peril. Baltazar Pacimontanus wanted to introduce a new form to his new church and disperse the whole church. And what did Oecolampadius, a holy and learned man from Basel, bring about? Was there less impiety among them? What did certain ones bring about in St. Gall, against whom our most prudent, pious and learned teacher Zwingli so strongly protested? Or what could we safely attempt in these turbulent other times? Could we perhaps provide an opportunity for certain impious people, so that they might be able to bring to fruition that which they had already conceived earlier, faster now with our help? Remove then from the senate what you desire; entrust it to certain persons. But who will really fear them?

seg.output: What need is there for many words? I too can entrust certain persons with the authority of excommunication if only this would bring glory to God in our city or if we could achieve something better through this innovation or if this would enable us to more strongly oppose the wicked and impiety than we have been able to so far. For everything should be done by us for the edification and carefully done, lest we bring the church into the greatest danger. Baltazar Pacimontanus wanted to introduce a new form of his city to the new church and disperse the entire church. And what did Oecolampadius, a holy and universally learned man, promote among the Basel? Or was there less impiety among them? What did some of them promote at St Gallen, to whom our most prudent, pious and learned teacher Zuinglius was so reluctant? Or what could we safely try in these turbulent times? Perhaps giving an opportunity to some wicked people so that what they have been planning for a long time can now be accomplished more quickly through our efforts? Remove from the senate what you desire; entrust certain people with it. But who will fear them? Let a cinericius be called by them; they will despise it. Let them be excommunicated; they will stir up the crowd and the church will be divided. But I don't want, you say, to be ejected and excommunicated to be despised. But he is most abjectly despised who is ejected from the fellowship of the saints. But, you say, let him keep what belongs to him and leave us our unharmed. He will not do it. So, you will say, it will be a holy persecution. But it will not necessarily be called by us, not imposed on us by God. For we can freely preach the truth, confess Christ freely and enjoy all the benefits of the Church. One thing is missing: you want to bring cinericios and lice into order with excommunication. But beware that in this way we do not restore all the wicked to freedom, with which we wanted to force them into order, so that from then on they take away from us all freedom of speech, action and confession. Rather, let us preach Christ holily, rebuke sins prophetically, urge the magistrate to remember his duty wisely.

seg.output: What need is there for many people? I too can confer upon certain individuals the authority of excommunication, provided that this measure brings glory to God in our city, or that we have done something better by this innovation, or that we can oppose the wicked and impiety more strongly than hitherto. For all things should be done by us unto edification and done with caution, lest we bring the church into the utmost peril. Baltazar Pacimontanus wanted to bring a new form of his city to the new church and dispersed the whole church. And what did Oecolampadius, a holy man and most learned everywhere, promote among the Basel? Or did less impiety prevail among them? What did some among the people of St Gall do, against whom our most prudent, pious, and learned teacher Zwingli so strongly contended? Or what could we safely venture in these turbulent times? Perhaps to give opportunity to some impious to bring forth that which they had long ago conceived, that it might now be brought forth more quickly by our own effort? Take away, you say, from the senate what you wish; confer it upon certain individuals. But who will reverence them? Let some cinder-man be called by them; he will despise. Let him be excommunicated; he will stir up the people and the church will be rent asunder. But I do not wish, you say, that an ejected and excommunicated person be contemned. But he is most abjectly contemned who is cast out of the fellowship of the saints. But, you say, let him have his own and leave ours undisturbed. He will not. Sancta therefore, says, will be the persecution, but not necessarily brought upon us by us, nor sent by God unto us. For we can freely preach the truth, freely confess Christ, and enjoy all the privileges which the church enjoys. This only is wanting: you wish by excommunication to reduce cinder-men and lice into order. But take heed lest by the same means we restore all impious persons to liberty, whom we would have brought into order, that they may thenceforth deprive us of all liberty of speaking, doing, and confessing. Rather let us preach Christ holily, denounce sin prophetically, urge the magistrate that he duly remember his office. Let us admonish the pious to live piously, and let each one prove himself in receiving the sacrament, especially when we see that Judas received the sacrament of the body and blood of Christ; or, what say I of Judas? I know that all the apostles received it, who after one or two hours fell away from Christ, so that Peter thrice denied that he knew him.

seg.output: What need is there for many? I too can confer the authority of excommunication on certain men, provided only that this should bring glory to God in our city, or that we should do something better by this innovation, or be able to more strongly resist the wicked and impiety than we have hitherto. For all things must be done by us for the edification, and done with circumspection, lest we cast the Church into extreme danger. Baltazar Pacimontanus wished to introduce a new form of Church into his city and dispersed the whole Church. What did Oecolampadius, a holy and learned man in all respects, promote among the Basilienses? Was impiety any less among them? What did some once promote at St. Gall, which was so much resisted by our excellent, pious and learned teacher Zwingli? Or what could we safely attempt in these turbulent times? Perhaps to give the wicked some opportunity, that what they have already conceived they might now bring forth with the help of our work? Take away, then, what you wish from the Senate; confer the authority on certain men. But who will respect them? Let some cinerary be called by them; he shall be contemned. Let him be excommunicated; he will raise a tumult, and thus the Church will be divided. But I do not wish, say you, that he who is ejected and excommunicated should be contemned. But he is most miserably contemned who is ejected from the fellowship of the saints. But, you say, let him keep his to himself, and let us leave our undefiled. He will not do it. But, you will say, this will be a holy persecution. But it will not be necessarily by us, nor sent by God to us. For we can freely preach the truth, freely confess Christ, and enjoy all things which the Church enjoys. There is one thing wanting: By excommunication you wish to reduce the cineraries and lice into order. But take heed lest we restore all the wicked to their liberty, by the very means which we intended to reduce them to order, whereby they may hereafter snatch from us all liberty of speaking, acting, and confessing. Rather let us preach Christ holily, let us reprove sins prophetically, let us exhort the magistrates, let them remember their office. Let us sometimes threaten, unless they more severely punish crimes, that we will commit excommunication to others. Let us admonish the pious to live holily, and let every one take care to prove himself worthy in the reception of the sacraments, especially when we see that Judas partook of the sacrament of the body and blood of Christ; nay, what say I of Judas, who I know all the apostles partook, who after one or two hours fell off from Christ, so that even Peter denied Him holily. Let us therefore admonish the pious, let us again and again admonish them, let us gather our Church together in faith and doctrine.

seg.output: What then is needed by many? I too can confer the authority of excommunication upon certain men, provided that this course of action brings glory to our city or that we have done something better by this innovation or that we may be better able to withstand the wicked and ungodly by this means than we have hitherto. For all things should be done by us for edification and done carefully lest we bring the Church into the utmost danger. Baltazar Pacimontanus wanted to introduce a new form of his city to the new Church and dispersed the whole Church. And what did Oecolampadius, a holy and widely learned man, promote among the Baselians? Was there any less impiety among them? What did some of them promote at St. Gall a while ago, whom the most prudent, pious, and learned teacher of ours, Zwingli, so greatly opposed? Or what could we safely attempt in these turbulent other times? Perhaps to give an opportunity to certain wicked people, that what they have already conceived may be brought forth the sooner by our work? Take away from the senate what you wish; confer the authority upon certain men. Who, however, will fear them? Let a cineritious one be called by them; he will despise. Let him be excommunicated; he will raise a tumult and thus the Church will be split. But, you say, I do not wish the ejected and excommunicated to be despised. But he is most abjectly despised who is cast out from the fellowship of the saints. But, you say, let him keep his own and leave us ours unhurt. He will not do it. So, you say, it will be an holy persecution. But not necessarily brought upon us by ourselves, not sent upon us by God. For we may freely preach the truth, freely confess Christ, and enjoy all the blessings which the Church enjoys. One thing is wanting: you wish to reduce the cineritious and lice-ridden to order by excommunication. But take care, lest by the very same means we should restore all the wicked to liberty, by which we have wished to reduce them to order, that they may thenceforward snatch from us all freedom of speech, action, and confession. Rather let us preach Christ holily, rebuke sins prophetically, urge the magistrates wisely that they remember their office. Let us sometimes threaten, unless they more severely punish wickedness, that we will commit the excommunication to others. Let us admonish the godly to lead a holy life, and let each prove himself in the reception of the sacraments, especially when we see that Judas received the sacrament of the body and blood of Christ; yea, what do I say Judas, when I know that all the apostles received it, who after an hour or two fell away from Christ, so that Peter himself denied the Lord with an oath. Let us therefore again and again admonish the godly, gather our Church together in faith and doctrine. He that is of God, hath his own seal.

seg.input: In hoc tota versatur epistola , Leo doctissime, ut magistratui, qualiscunque tandem sit, non committatur quicquam ecclesiasticarum rerum. Addis causam: «Magistratus enim et ecclesia res sunt diversissimae. Alterum enim super res est et corpora, alterum super animas.» Et sane lubricum agimus negotium, si quisquam viribus contendere malit quam simplicissimum negotium non curiosa suscipere mente, cum, quod contentiosis nihil tam bene dici possit, quod non aliquam secum afferat reprehendendi ansam, tum, quod singula verba aliter ac aliter usurpari possunt. Quod equidem maximarum contentionum semper fuit inter summos etiam viros feracissimum seminarium. Ego enim hanc propositionem («magistratus et ecclesia sunt res diversissimae») non video quomodo universaliter possit esse vera. Si enim Pilati, Caiaphae, Herodis et Iudaicae synagogae magistratum adferas , iam tyrannos, non magistratus attulisti. Impius magistratus mancus et mutilus est magistratus. 1. Quod si tu magistratum non tam ex functione aestimes quam ex iis, qui gerunt magistratum, iam si duo aut tres consentiant super terram, etsi magistratum gerant, certe ecclesiam, si Christo credimus , constituunt. Rursus, si magistratum gerere est ministrum dei esse , si christianus potest minister dei esse, id quod adversus catabaptistas obtinuimus , 2. iam etsi ethnici aliquo modo possint ministri dei esse veluti Nebuch[adonosor] et Sanherib, nemo tamen melius norit deo ministrare quam christianus. 3. Ecclesia item christianorum sit collectio. Iam non video, quid sibi velint ista tua verba: «Magistratus et ecclesia sunt res diversissimae. Nihil ecclesiasticarum rerum committatur magistratui, qualiscunque tandem sit.» 4. Quod si functionem quoque magistratus spectas eamque ad separationem ecclesiae et magistratus referas, iam Paulus: «Principes», inquit, «non terrori sunt bene agentibus, sed male». Item: «Dei minister est, ultor ad iram ei, qui, quod malum est, fecerit» [Röm 13,3f]. Atque nullibi exactius invenias discrimen boni et mali quam in ecclesia, quae verbo veritatis regitur. Et gentes incredulique bene agentibus terrori sunt, christiani vero male agentibus terrori sunt. 5. Et spiritus sanctus de magistratu eligendo: «Provide» , inquit, «de omni plebe viros fortes, timentes deum, in quibus sit veritas et qui oderint avaritiam, et ex iis constitue senatores, qui iudicent populum omni tempore» [Ex 18,21f]. Haec magistratum gerentibus vereque gerentibus regula. Sed quis non commiserit viris prudentibus, fortibus et deum timentibus res ecclesiae sanctas? Proinde iterum non video, quomodo constet ista tua propositio: «Magistratui, qualiscunque tandem sit, non committatur quicquam rerum ecclesiasticarum», item illa: «Magistratus et ecclesia res sunt diversissimae» .
seg.output: This entire letter revolves around this, Leo, most learned one, that nothing ecclesiastical should be entrusted to the magistracy, whatever kind it may be. You add the reason: "For the magistracy and the church are things of the utmost diversity; the one has to do with bodies and the other with souls." And indeed we are managing a slippery business, if anyone would rather try his strength than take up in good faith the most simple matter, when, since nothing can be so well said in a contentious matter that it does not bring with it some occasion for blame, and because single words can be used this way and that, this has always been a most fertile source of the greatest contentions even among the most eminent men. For I do not see how this proposition ("the magistracy and the church are things of the utmost diversity") can be universally true. For if you bring in the magistracy of Pilate, Caiaphas, Herod, and the Jewish synagogue, you have now brought in tyrants, not magistrates. An impious magistrate is a maimed and mutilated magistrate. But if you regard the magistrate not so much from his function but from those who bear the magistracy, then if two or three agree on earth, even though they bear the magistracy, they certainly constitute a church, if we believe in Christ. Again, if it is to be the minister of God to bear the magistracy, and if a Christian can be the minister of God, which we have established against the Anabaptists, then even though the heathen can in some manner be the ministers of God, like Nebuchadnezzar and Sennacherib, yet no one knows better how to serve God than a Christian. Also, the Church of Christians is a collection. Now I do not understand what your words mean: "The magistracy and the church are things of the utmost diversity. Nothing ecclesiastical should be entrusted to the magistracy, whatever kind it may be." But if you also consider the function of the magistrate and refer it to the separation of the Church and the magistrate, then Paul says: "Rulers are not a terror to good works, but to the evil" [Romans 13:3-4]. Also: "He is the minister of God to you for good. But if you do what is evil, be afraid; for he does not bear the sword in vain; for he is the minister of God, a revenger to execute wrath on him who practices evil" [Romans 13:4]. And nowhere more clearly can you find the distinction between good and evil than in the Church, which is ruled by the word of truth. And the heathen and unbelievers are a terror to the good, but the Christians are a terror to the evil. And the Holy Spirit concerning the choice of a magistrate: "You shall provide out of all the people able men, such as fear God, men of truth, hating covetousness; and place such over them, to be rulers of thousands, and rulers of hundreds, rulers of fifties, and rulers of tens" [Exodus 18:21-22]. This is a true and proper rule for those who bear the magistracy. But who would not commit the holy things of the Church to prudent, strong, and God-fearing men? Therefore again I do not see how your proposition can stand: "Nothing ecclesiastical should be entrusted to the magistracy, whatever kind it may be," as well as this one: "The magistracy and the church are things of the utmost diversity."

Ecclesia enim, quae sola animas regit, a nullo magistratu regitur.
This whole letter revolves around Leo, most learned, so that nothing ecclesiastical may be entrusted to any magistrate, whatever he may be. You add the reason: "For magistrates and the church are very different things; the one is over bodies, the other over souls." And indeed we are dealing with a slippery business, if anyone should prefer to contend with force rather than to take up the most simple matter with an uninquisitive mind, since, as nothing can be said so well as to give no handle for reproof to the contentious, and as single words can be used in various senses, so this has ever been a most fruitful source of great disputes even among the greatest men. For I do not see how the proposition, "magistrates and the church are very different things," can be universally true. For if you bring Pilate, Caiaphas, Herod, and the Jewish Synagogue, you have brought tyrants, not magistrates. An impious magistrate is a maimed and mutilated magistrate. But if you consider the magistrate, not so much according to his function, as to those who bear the office, now if two or three agree together upon earth, though they bear the office of magistrate, yet, if we believe in Christ, they constitute the church. Again, if it be to be a minister of God to bear the office of magistrate, and if a Christian can be a minister of God, which we have maintained against the Anabaptists, then, though the heathen may in some manner be ministers of God, as Nebuchadnezzar and Sennacherib, yet none will know better how to minister unto God than a Christian. Moreover, the church of Christians is a collection. Now I do not see what your words mean, "The magistrate and the church are very different things; nothing of ecclesiastical matters should be entrusted to the magistrate, whatever he may be." But if you also regard the function of the magistrate, and refer it to the separation of the church and the magistrate, then Paul saith, "Rulers are not a terror to the good work, but to the evil" (Rom. 13:3-4). And also, "The minister of God is a revenger to execute wrath upon him that doeth evil" (Rom. 13:4). And nowhere is the distinction between good and evil more exactly made than in the church, which is ruled by the word of truth. And the heathen and unbelievers are a terror to the good, but Christians to the evil. And the Holy Ghost, in choosing a magistrate, saith, "Provide out of all the people able men, such as fear God, in whom there is truth, and that hate covetousness, and appoint them rulers of the people" (Ex. 18:21-22). This is a rule for those who bear the office of magistrate, and truly bear it. But who will not commit the holy things of the church to wise, strong, and God-fearing men? Wherefore I again see not how your proposition, "Nothing of ecclesiastical matters should be entrusted to the magistrate, whatever he may be," and also, "The magistrate and the church are very different things," can stand. Moreover, I know not whether any magistrate is set over souls in the church. For the church, which alone rules souls, is ruled by no magistrate.

Therefore I see not how this proposition of yours can stand ‘Let nothing ecclesiastical be committed to the magistrate, whatsoever he be’, and also ‘The magistrate and the church are very different things.’ 6. Besides, I know not whether any magistrate be set over the souls in the church. I deny not that power of binding and loosing is given to the apostles and their successors. 7. But whether it be given to the magistrate or not, I doubt.

In hoc tota versatur epistola , Leo doctissime, ut magistratui, qualiscunque tandem sit, non committatur quicquam ecclesiasticarum rerum. Addis causam: «Magistratus enim et ecclesia res sunt diversissimae. Alterum enim super res est et corpora, alterum super animas.» Et sane lubricum agimus negotium, si quisquam viribus contendere malit quam simplicissimum negotium non curiosa suscipere mente, cum, quod contentiosis nihil tam bene dici possit, quod non aliquam secum afferat reprehendendi ansam, tum, quod singula verba aliter ac aliter usurpari possunt. Quod equidem maximarum contentionum semper fuit inter summos etiam viros feracissimum seminarium. Ego enim hanc propositionem («magistratus et ecclesia sunt res diversissimae») non video quomodo universaliter possit esse vera. Si enim Pilati, Caiaphae, Herodis et Iudaicae synagogae magistratum adferas , iam tyrannos, non magistratus attulisti. Impius magistratus mancus et mutilus est magistratus. 1. Quod si tu magistratum non tam ex functione aestimes quam ex iis, qui gerunt magistratum, iam si duo aut tres consentiant super terram, etsi magistratum gerant, certe ecclesiam, si Christo credimus , constituunt. Rursus, si magistratum gerere est ministrum dei esse , si christianus potest minister dei esse, id quod adversus catabaptistas obtinuimus , 2. iam etsi ethnici aliquo modo possint ministri dei esse veluti Nebuch[adonosor] et Sanherib, nemo tamen melius norit deo ministrare quam christianus. 3. Ecclesia item christianorum sit collectio. Iam non video, quid sibi velint ista tua verba: «Magistratus et ecclesia sunt res diversissimae. Nihil ecclesiasticarum rerum committatur magistratui, qualiscunque tandem sit.» 4. Quod si functionem quoque magistratus spectas eamque ad separationem ecclesiae et magistratus referas, iam Paulus: «Principes», inquit, «non terrori sunt bene agentibus, sed male». Item: «Dei minister est, ultor ad iram ei, qui, quod malum est, fecerit» [Röm 13,3f]. Atque nullibi exactius invenias discrimen boni et mali quam in ecclesia, quae verbo veritatis regitur. Et gentes incredulique bene agentibus terrori sunt, christiani vero male agentibus terrori sunt. 5. Et spiritus sanctus de magistratu eligendo: «Provide» , inquit, «de omni plebe viros fortes, timentes deum, in quibus sit veritas et qui oderint avaritiam, et ex iis constitue senatores, qui iudicent populum omni tempore» [Ex 18,21f]. Haec magistratum gerentibus vereque gerentibus regula. Sed quis non commiserit viris prudentibus, fortibus et deum timentibus res ecclesiae sanctas? Proinde iterum non video, quomodo constet ista tua propositio: «Magistratui, qualiscunque tandem sit, non committatur quicquam rerum ecclesiasticarum», item illa: «Magistratus et ecclesia res sunt diversissimae» . 6. Deinde nescio, si aliquis magistratus in ecclesia super animas sit constitutus. Non nego ligandi et solvendi potestatem datam esse apostolis et successoribus . Sed Zuinglio praeceptore didicimus clavium potestatem evangelii esse praedicationem, quae aliis mortem minatur, aliis pollicetur vitam .

seg.output:
In this whole letter, Leo, most learned man, it is proposed that nothing of a spiritual nature be entrusted to whatever magistrate. The reason is given: "For magistrates and the Church are very different things; one is concerned with matters of the body, the other with those of the soul." And indeed we are dealing with a slippery business if anyone would rather strive with his strength than take up the simplest task with an uninquisitive mind, since there is nothing so likely to give rise to controversy as that which can be interpreted in various ways, and since each single word can be used in different senses. This has ever been a very fruitful source of the most violent disputes even among the greatest men. For myself, I see no way in which the proposition "magistrates and the Church are very different things" can be universally true. For if you bring forward Pilate, Caiaphas, Herod and the Jewish sanhedrin, you have offered up tyrants, not magistrates. An impious magistrate is an armless and maimless magistrate. If you view a magistrate not so much from his office as from those who fill the office, now if two or three agree on the earth, although they may exercise a magistracy, yet, if we believe Christ, they do indeed constitute a Church. Again, if it be to be a minister of God to exercise a magistracy, and if a Christian can be a minister of God—a point we have won against the Anabaptists—now although heathens can in some sense be ministers of God, as in the cases of Nebuchadnezzar and Sennacherib, yet no one knows better how to serve God than a Christian. The Church of the Christians is a collection. Now I do not understand what your words mean: "Magistrates and the Church are very different things; nothing spiritual should be committed to whatever magistrate." If you also look to the function of the magistrate and refer it to the separation of the Church and the magistrate, look at Paul, "Rulers are not a terror to good works, but to the evil," and, "He is the minister of God to thee for good." And there is no place where the distinction between good and evil is more accurately marked than in the Church, which is ruled by the word of truth. And the heathen and the unbelievers are a terror to the good, but to the evil the Christians are a terror. And the Holy Spirit regarding the election of magistrates, says, "Provide out of all the people able men such as fear God, in whom there is truth, and that hate covetousness; and place such over them, to be rulers of thousands, and rulers of hundreds." This is a true and genuine rule for those who exercise a magistracy. But who would not commit to prudent, brave and God-fearing men the holy things of the Church? Wherefore again I see no way in which your proposition can stand, "Whatever magistrate, nothing spiritual should be committed to him," or this one, "Magistrates and the Church are very different things." Furthermore, I do not know if any magistrate is appointed over souls in the Church. I do not deny that the power of binding and loosing was given to the apostles and their successors. But under Zuinglius we have learned that the power of the keys is the preaching of the gospel, which threatens death to some, and promises life to others.
As for excommunication, which may well have seemed to be imposed on souls by a spiritual authority, it is certain that a man's sin is forgiven when he returns to the Lord through faith. Witnesses are the prodigal son, the publican, Peter and the thief, etc. From this it follows that excommunication is not a punishment of the soul and internal, but external and inflicted for the sake of scandal. Which Paul expresses most significantly when he says of the fornicator, "Deliver such an one unto Satan for the destruction of the flesh" [1 Cor. 5.5].

As far as excommunication is concerned, which may have seemed to be imposed on souls by spiritual authority, it is certain that the sin of a man is forgiven when he returns to the Lord through faith. The prodigal son, the tax collector, Peter, and the thief stand as witnesses. Therefore, it follows that excommunication is not of the soul and internal, but an external penalty inflicted due to scandal. Paul expressed this very significantly when he said about the fornicator, "Let him be handed over to Satan for the destruction of the flesh" [1 Corinthians 5:5]. What is handing over to Satan other than to cast into adversity and afflict? Thus Job was also handed over to Satan. And what is the destruction of the flesh other than an external penalty or suppression, chastisement, or mortification of the flesh? Whether it is done by contempt, neglect, or any other method, as long as it is done and public decency is defended. Additionally, in 2 Corinthians 2 [6], he wrote the same, "This punishment is enough for such a man," that is, penalty and correction. But you consult G. Budaeus on the power of the words τιμάν και τιμάσΒαι, and a very clear light will come. Therefore, what prevents, since excommunication is an external penalty, from entrusting it to the magistrate piously, not only in name of the magistrate, but because it is entrusted by the church? As Zuinglius and you, or rather the whole church, have entrusted this office to the senate, assuming he wrote truly in the "Subsidio".
However, I am not arguing that this office should be assigned only to the magistrate or that it should be entrusted to no one but him, nor did I wish to assert this in my previous letter to Berchtold; but I argued against the Anabaptists who attribute it to the common people and their own faction, which they call the church, so that it would not have been necessary for yours. However, after much discussion, you end up saying that excommunication is of the church or of the elders to whom the church has been entrusted. I say the same and hold the same opinion, indeed I deduce from this that if it is entrusted to the magistrate, then excommunication is already with him, that is, public crimes are subjected to public and external penalties. However, here you think nothing should be entrusted to the magistrate, whatever it may be.

But here you do not think that anything should be entrusted to the magistrate, whatever it may be. About this, above. Since the magistrate is wicked, you say, was he any different then, when the administration of diocesan and matrimonial causes was entrusted to him? Rather, he was much more pernicious then. It will never come about that our affairs will be restored to the point that the church, which we can better imagine than see, will be composed of such rulers, as we want or wish for them to be holy, unstained, and perfected in every way. That was once proved to us in the two highest orders of the church. For among the very few apostles there was a betrayer, and among the seven deacons, Nicolas the heretic. But the rest were not immediately to be despised on the name of some or deprived of their function.

Videndum est, ut in ecclesia pacem habeamus, quam optamus.
It is now impossible for our church to be composed of the kind of leaders we desire or wish for, holy, untainted and perfect in every way. This has already been proven to us in the two greatest orders of the church. For among the few apostles, a traitor was found, and among the seven deacons, Nicholas was a heretic. But the rest were not immediately condemned or deprived of their office in the name of some. For it is one thing when we are forced to submit to the suffrage of the wicked, and another when, even if the wicked are present, they are subject to the law. Among the Gentiles, usury, fornication, drunkenness, etc. were not punished by every magistrate, nor had every magistrate prohibited these things. But with us, these are so connected with civil constitutions, as if they were in a Christian state, that if a few of the wicked should protest, they are nevertheless guilty of violating the law, and the just cannot with any justice be compelled to agree with them. For the public edict, the public constitution, is constantly opposed to it, by which now both good men and bishops can be urged. Add to this, that we have not avoided this danger, even if we have taken away the penalty of crimes from the magistrates and assigned them to certain men from the church, as if, indeed, those men could not be Ananiases, Demas, and many others, and could not express the example of the many. For the illustrious man Zwingli wrote in vain against the Anabaptists, that our calamity is so great, that we have not yet found among men so absolute a perfection, nor is it to be hoped that all who confess Christ will be perfect in every way, so long as this earthly dwelling-place is borne about.
Therefore, since it is now necessary for us to act as we can (unless we would rather disturb all things), when it is not allowed to do as we would, I look solely to this, that we may have a peaceful church and one not altogether shamelessly sinning; a church indeed not without tribulations—for all who will live piously in Christ must needs be afflicted—but a church as to those who are in it, free from sin; and not altogether shamelessly sinning. For we are men, so long as we live; therefore let nothing human be alien to us. Wherefore, since it is now necessary for us to act as we can (unless we would rather disturb all things), when it is not allowed to do as we would, I look solely to this, that we may have a peaceful church and one not altogether shamelessly sinning; a church indeed not without tribulations—for all who will live piously in Christ must needs be afflicted—but a church as to those who are in it, free from sin; and not altogether shamelessly sinning. For the best men are sometimes deceived and the highest wits often ensnared. Wherefore, since it is now necessary for us to act as we can (unless we would rather disturb all things), when it is not allowed to do as we would, I look solely to this, that we may have a peaceful church and one not altogether shamelessly sinning; a church indeed not without tribulations—for all who will live piously in Christ must needs be afflicted—but a church as to those who are in it, free from sin; and not altogether shamelessly sinning. For we are men, so long as we live; therefore let nothing human be alien to us. The best men too, fail, but they return in their due time. What need of many words? We must endeavour to have peace in the church, which we desire.

Therefore, since we must act as best we can (unless we prefer to mix up everything in confusion), since we cannot act as we would like, I now focus exclusively on having a peaceful church that is not completely impudently sinning, peaceful certainly not without tribulations - for all who wish to live piously in Christ must be afflicted -, but peaceful as far as those who are in the church are concerned; and not completely impudently sinning. For we are men as long as we live; therefore, nothing human will be alien to us. Even the best of people are deceived by sin and often the greatest minds are overtaken by it. What more need be said? We are men. And here we are speaking of external church, not the internal, which, after charity, has no need of laws, but is still glad of public edicts as being set up for the punishment of evil. The good hate to sin out of love of virtue, the wicked hate to sin out of fear of punishment. The pious do what is just out of love of justice, the impious have the law set against them. In the external church, which Christ described in Matthew 13 [24ff], there is need of external punishment, which is excommunication. In this severity of discipline the wicked must be restrained.

I too can entrust the power of excommunication to certain men, provided that this course of action would bring glory to God and we could do something better through this innovation, or if we could more strongly oppose the impious and impiety than we have done thus far. Aut quid in hisce turbulentis alias temporibus tuto tentare possemus? Ansam fortassis dare impiis quibusdam, ut quod iam olim parturierunt, id nunc nostra opera celerius parere possint? Aufer enim a senatu, quod cupis; demanda certis viris. Quis vero illos verebitur? Vocetur ab iis cinericius aliquis; contemnet. Excommunicetur; turbas movebit et ita scindetur ecclesia. At nolo, inquis, eiectus et excommunicatus contemnatur . Sed abiectissime contemptus est, qui e sanctorum consortio eiectus est. Ceterum, sua sibi habeat, inquis, nobis nostra illibata relinquat . Non faciet. Sancta ergo erit persecutio , dices. Sed a nobis ipsis non necessario ascita, non a deo nobis immissa. Libere enim veritatem praedicare possumus, libere Christum confiteri et omnibus, quibus ecclesia gaudet, frui. Unum deest: Excommunicatione vis cinericios et pediculos redigere in ordinem . Sed videndum, ne eo ipso medio in libertatem impios omnes restituamus, quo voluimus in ordinem cogere, ut deinceps nobis omnem eripiant et dicendi et agendi et confitendi libertatem. Quin potius praedicemus Christum sancte, culpemus scelera prophetice, urgeamus magistratum scite sui meminerit officii. Minitemur aliquoties, nisi severius animadvertant in scelera, iam excommunicationem aliis commissuros. Moneamus pios pie vivant, et in perceptione sacramentorum quisque sese probet , maxime cum videamus Iudam corporis et sanguinis Christi sacramentum percepisse ; imo quid Iudam dico, qui scio omnes apostolos percepisse, qui post horam unam aut alteram desciverunt a Christo , adeo ut et Petrus sancte deiuraret se hominem non nosse . Moneamus ergo pios, iterum atque iterum moneamus, colligamus ecclesiam nostram in fide et doctrina. Qui dei est, habet suum signaculum . Perversi in dies in deterius feruntur.
seg.output:
Quidquid vero hac de re a nobis statuatur, hoc unum tenendis est, nequaquam praesumendum esse de deo, neque impiis parcendum , neque in ecclesia dei sceleribus veniam dandam .
What need have we of many things? I too can demand the authority of excommunication from certain men, provided this innovation brings glory to our city, or we do something better by it, or by this means we can more strongly oppose the wicked and their impiety than hitherto. For all things ought to be done by us for edification, and carefully, lest we bring the Church into the utmost danger. Baltazar Pacimontanus wished to introduce a new form of government to his new Church, and scattered the whole Church. And what did Oecolampadius, a holy and everywhere most learned man, promote at Basle? Or did he promote less impiety there? What did some at St. Gall formerly promote, to whom our most prudent, pious and learned teacher Zwingli showed so great reluctance? Or what could we safely attempt in these turbulent times? Would we perhaps give occasion to some wicked persons, that what they had already conceived might now sooner come to pass by our means? Take away, then, what you wish from the Senate; demand it of certain men. Who will fear them? Let a certain cinder-man be called; he will despise it. Let him be excommunicated; he will raise a tumult and so the Church will be divided. But, you say, I wish the ejected and excommunicated to be not despised. But he is most abjectly despised who is cast out from the society of the saints. But, you say, let him keep his own, and let ours remain untouched. He will not do so. You will say, It will be a holy persecution. But not necessarily brought upon us by God, or inflicted by Him upon us. We can freely preach the truth, freely confess Christ, and enjoy all the privileges of the Church. One thing is wanting: You would have the cinders and lice reduced to order by excommunication. But we must take care lest, by that very same means, we restore to liberty all the wicked, whom we intended to bring into order, that so they may hereafter deprive us of all liberty of speaking, doing, and confessing. Rather let us preach Christ holily, denounce wickedness prophetically, urge the magistrate skilfully to remember his office. Let us threaten him several times, unless he more severely punish wickedness, that we may have to commit excommunication to others. Let us exhort the pious to live piously, and let every one prove himself in the reception of the sacraments, especially when we see Judas receive the sacrament of the body and blood of Christ; nay, what do I say of Judas, when I know all the apostles received it, who, after one or two hours, fell away from Christ, so that Peter denied Him in holy fear. Let us therefore exhort the pious again and again; let us gather our Church together in faith and doctrine. He that is of God hath His seal. The perverse go from bad to worse. Whatever is determined by us concerning this matter, this one thing must be held fast: We must by no means presume upon God, nor show mercy to the wicked, nor grant pardon for wickedness in the Church of God.

What is the need for many things? I too can grant the authority of excommunication to certain men, provided that it would bring glory to God to our city or we could do something better through this innovation, or we could more strongly oppose impiety and impiety than we have done so far. For all things should be done by us for edification and done carefully, lest we throw the church into the greatest danger. Baltazar Pacimontanus wanted to introduce a new form of his city to the new church and dispersed the whole church. And what did Oecolampadius, a holy and learned man in all places, promote among the Baselese? Or did he do less impiety among them? What did some of them do in St. Gallen in the past, which our most prudent, pious and learned teacher Zwingli so strongly resisted? Or what could we safely try in these turbulent times? Could we perhaps give the opportunity to some impious to bring forth what they have already conceived, so that they could bring it forth faster through our work? Take away from the senate what you want; assign certain men. Who will fear them? Let a cinericius be called by them; he will despise it. Let him be excommunicated; he will stir up the crowd and thus the church will be divided. But I do not want, you say, that the ejected and excommunicated should be despised. But he is most contemptuously despised who has been cast out of the fellowship of the saints. But, you say, let him have his own and leave us our own untouched. He will not do it. So, you say, it will be a holy persecution. But not necessarily brought on by ourselves, not sent by God to us. For we can freely preach the truth, confess Christ freely and enjoy all the things the church has to offer. One thing is missing: with excommunication you want to reduce cinericii and lice to order. But we must be careful not to restore all the impious to freedom by the very means by which we wanted to compel them to order, so that they could then deprive us of all freedom of speech, action and confession. Rather, let us preach Christ holily, prophesy crimes, urge the magistrate to remember his office wisely. We may threaten a few times, unless they take a more serious view of the crimes, we shall now commit excommunication to others. Let us admonish the pious to live piously, and let each one prove himself in the reception of the sacraments, especially when we see Judas taking the sacrament of the body and blood of Christ; I speak not of Judas, for I know all the apostles took it, who after an hour or two defected from Christ, so that even Peter holily denied that he knew no man. Let us therefore admonish the pious, again and again admonish, gather our church in faith and doctrine. He who is of God, has his seal. The wicked grow worse and worse in the day. The impious are excommunicated by God, and all who believe in the preached gospel shun and avoid our impious; they are careful of themselves from them. But what is the effect on the pious and on the apostles, since Judas communicates with them? He takes his own judgement. The pious come in faith.

seg.output: I wanted to make a few notes, Leo, the most learned teacher and my dearest brother. For I did not want to respond to each one separately, lest brothers and friends would contend more bitterly. Nor do I think that you think I am taking the worse side, nor do I bear anything with difficulty. There is no need for any discussions with me. I love you and venerate your learning and your age full of authority. I can see and understand your mind, which is indeed holy and sincere. Therefore, I wanted to discuss this matter with more people, whom I believe you wanted to examine closely, what I can do in sacred matters: certainly, what you see and hear every day is little or nothing. What could be more clear? If we consider simply what excommunication is, namely, the public guardianship of public decency, and why it was instituted, namely, lest people sin more impudently in the Church of Christ, and that it was given especially to external churches, again, if we consider what flesh is, and that we are and remain men at all times of life, so that the spirit may be ready, finally, that we can hope for an unpolluted church faster than we can have it, the matter will be easy. We would sooner establish a Novatian church than one perfect in all respects.
