seg.output:
I wanted to make a few notes for you, Leo, my most learned teacher and dearest brother. I did not want to respond to each individual point, lest we brothers and companions dispute more bitterly. Nor do I assume that I am interpreting anything in a worse light, nor do I take offence at anything. No entreaties are necessary with me. I love you and revere your erudition and the fullness of your authority in your old age. I can see and clearly see your mind, which is indeed holy and sincere. For this reason I wanted to deal with this matter in more detail, so that I could be sure that you wanted to examine these things, what I can do regarding sacred matters. Certainly, what you see and hear every day is little or certainly nothing. For what could be more evident? If we consider simply what excommunication is, namely a public safeguard of public decency, and why it was instituted, namely, so that they may not sin more impudently in the church of Christ, and what was given to the external church in particular, then if we examine what flesh is, and that we humans are and remain flesh at all times of life, so that the spirit is prompt, and finally that we can hope for an unpolluted church more quickly than we can have it, then the matter will already be easy. We will also not be able to make the world differently than it was from the beginning. We would sooner establish the Novatian church than one that is perfect in all respects. The Lord, through Zwingli and you, has advanced the church of Zurich, so that I may believe that I have been a faithful servant of God, if I can keep it through his grace and your help, as you have instituted it.
Farewell, and keep me in your thoughts.
March 15th, 1532.

seg.input: Quid vero multis opus? Possum et ego certis viris demandare excommunicationis authoritatem, si modo ea ratio urbi nostrae inducta gloriam dei promoveret aut nos ista innovatione melius aliquid fecerimus aut hac ratione impiis et impietati fortius quam hactenus obstare possemus. Nam omnia debent a nobis ad aedificationem fieri et circumspecte fieri, ne ecclesiam in summum coniiciamus discrimen. Volebat Baltazar Pacimontanus novae ecclesię novam formam urbi suae inducere et universam ecclesiam dispersit . Et quid promovit apud Basilienses Oecolampadius , vir sanctus et undiquaque doctissimus ? An minus apud eos impietatis? Quid promoverunt olim apud Sanctogallum nonnulli , quibus adeo reluctabatur prudentissimus, piissimus et doctissimus praeceptor noster Zuinglius ? Aut quid in hisce turbulentis alias temporibus tuto tentare possemus? Ansam fortassis dare impiis quibusdam, ut quod iam olim parturierunt, id nunc nostra opera celerius parere possint? Aufer enim a senatu, quod cupis; demanda certis viris. Quis vero illos verebitur? Vocetur ab iis cinericius aliquis; contemnet. Excommunicetur; turbas movebit et ita scindetur ecclesia. At nolo, inquis, eiectus et excommunicatus contemnatur . Sed abiectissime contemptus est, qui e sanctorum consortio eiectus est. Ceterum, sua sibi habeat, inquis, nobis nostra illibata relinquat . Non faciet. Sancta ergo erit persecutio , dices. Sed a nobis ipsis non necessario ascita, non a deo nobis immissa. Libere enim veritatem praedicare possumus, libere Christum confiteri et omnibus, quibus ecclesia gaudet, frui. Unum deest: Excommunicatione vis cinericios et pediculos redigere in ordinem . Sed videndum, ne eo ipso medio in libertatem impios omnes restituamus, quo voluimus in ordinem cogere, ut deinceps nobis omnem eripiant et dicendi et agendi et confitendi libertatem. Quin potius praedicemus Christum sancte, culpemus scelera prophetice, urgeamus magistratum scite sui meminerit officii. Minitemur aliquoties, nisi severius animadvertant in scelera, iam excommunicationem aliis commissuros. Moneamus pios pie vivant, et in perceptione sacramentorum quisque sese probet , maxime cum videamus Iudam corporis et sanguinis Christi sacramentum percepisse ; imo quid Iudam dico, qui scio omnes apostolos percepisse, qui post horam unam aut alteram desciverunt a Christo , adeo ut et Petrus sancte deiuraret se hominem non nosse . Moneamus ergo pios, iterum atque iterum moneamus, colligamus ecclesiam nostram in fide et doctrina. Qui dei est, habet suum signaculum . Perversi in dies in deterius feruntur. Excommunicati sunt a deo impii, et nostros impios aversantur et evitant omnes, qui praedicato evangelio credunt; cavent sibi ab eis.
seg.output: What need is there of many? I too can assign to certain men the authority of excommunication, provided it be with a view to the advancement of the glory of God in our city, or that we may by this innovation effect something better, or that we may be enabled more effectually to oppose the impious and impiety than we have hitherto done. For all things ought to be done by us for edification, and done with caution, lest we bring the church into extreme danger. Baltazar Pacimontanus would have introduced a new form into his city, and scattered the whole church. But what did Oecolampadius, a holy and universally learned man, promote among the Baselians? Did he promote less impiety among them? What did some at St. Gall formerly promote, to whom our most prudent, pious, and learned teacher, Zwinglius, so much opposed? Or what can we safely attempt in these tumultuous times? Shall we perhaps give an opportunity to some impious persons, that they may more speedily bring to pass that which they have long been meditating? Take away, say you, from the senate what you wish; assign it to certain men. But who will fear them? Let a cineritious one be called; he will despise it. Let him be excommunicated; he will raise a tumult, and thus the church will be rent. But I would not, say you, that the ejected and excommunicated should be despised. But he is most basely despised who is ejected from the society of the saints. But let him, say you, have his own, and let him leave us our rights intact. He will not. Shall the persecution, say you, be then holy? But it will not be necessarily brought upon us by us, nor sent by God upon us. For we are at liberty to preach the truth, freely to confess Christ, and to enjoy all the privileges of the church. One thing is wanting: To reduce the cineritious and lice to order by excommunication. But let us take heed, lest by the same means by which we would bring them into order, we should restore all the impious to liberty, to the end that they may hereafter deprive us of all liberty of speaking, doing, and confessing. Rather let us preach Christ holily, let us foretell crimes prophetically, let us press the magistrate wisely to remember his duty. Let us threaten him sometimes, unless he more severely punish crimes, that we will commit excommunication to others. Let us admonish the pious to lead a holy life, and let every one prove himself in the reception of the sacraments, especially when we see that Judas received the sacrament of the body and blood of Christ; nay, what say I of Judas, when I know that all the apostles received it, who after one or two hours fell away from Christ, even so that Peter denied that he knew him. Let us therefore admonish the pious, again and again let us admonish them, let us gather our church together in faith and doctrine. He that is of God, hath his seal. The wicked are carried from bad to worse. The impious are excommunicated by God, and all that believe the preached Gospel shun and avoid our impious. Let them beware of them.

Et quid promovit apud Basilienses Oecolampadius , vir sanctus et undiquaque doctissimus ? An minus apud eos impietatis? Quid promoverunt olim apud Sanctogallum nonnulli , quibus adeo reluctabatur prudentissimus, piissimus et doctissimus praeceptor noster Zuinglius ? Aut quid in hisce turbulentis alias temporibus tuto tentare possemus? Ansam fortassis dare impiis quibusdam, ut quod iam olim parturierunt, id nunc nostra opera celerius parere possint? Aufer enim a senatu, quod cupis; demanda certis viris. Quis vero illos verebitur? Vocetur ab iis cinericius aliquis; contemnet. Excommunicetur; turbas movebit et ita scindetur ecclesia. At nolo, inquis, eiectus et excommunicatus contemnatur . Sed abiectissime contemptus est, qui e sanctorum consortio eiectus est. Ceterum, sua sibi habeat, inquis, nobis nostra illibata relinquat . Non faciet. Sancta ergo erit persecutio , dices. Sed a nobis ipsis non necessario ascita, non a deo nobis immissa. Libere enim veritatem praedicare possumus, libere Christum confiteri et omnibus, quibus ecclesia gaudet, frui. Unum deest: Excommunicatione vis cinericios et pediculos redigere in ordinem . Sed videndum, ne eo ipso medio in libertatem impios omnes restituamus, quo voluimus in ordinem cogere, ut deinceps nobis omnem eripiant et dicendi et agendi et confitendi libertatem. Quin potius praedicemus Christum sancte, culpemus scelera prophetice, urgeamus magistratum scite sui meminerit officii. Minitemur aliquoties, nisi severius animadvertant in scelera, iam excommunicationem aliis commissuros. Moneamus pios pie vivant, et in perceptione sacramentorum quisque sese probet , maxime cum videamus Iudam corporis et sanguinis Christi sacramentum percepisse ; imo quid Iudam dico, qui scio omnes apostolos percepisse, qui post horam unam aut alteram desciverunt a Christo , adeo ut et Petrus sancte deiuraret se hominem non nosse . Moneamus ergo pios, iterum atque iterum moneamus, colligamus ecclesiam nostram in fide et doctrina. Qui dei est, habet suum signaculum . Perversi in dies in deterius feruntur. Excommunicati sunt a deo impii, et nostros impios aversantur et evitant omnes, qui praedicato evangelio credunt; cavent sibi ab eis. Quid vero ad pios et ad apostolos, quod Iudas cum eis communicat ? Is sibi iudicium sumit .
seg.output: What good would it do to many people? I too can grant the authority of excommunication to certain men, provided that this way is brought to our city to promote the glory of God, or that we have done something better by this innovation, or that we can more strongly oppose impiety and impieties than before. For everything must be done by us for edification and must be done circumspectly, lest we cast the church into the greatest danger. Baltazar Pacimontanus wanted to introduce a new form of his city into the new church and dispersed the whole church. And what did Oecolampadius, a holy and all around learned man, promote among the Baselers? Or did they have less impiety? What did some promote once in St. Gall, to whom our most prudent, pious and learned teacher Zwingli was so unwilling? Or what could we safely attempt in these turbulent times? Perhaps give some impious people a handle, so that what they have already conceived may be produced more quickly through our work? Take away from the senate what you wish; assign to certain men. But who will make them fear? Let some Cinerite be called by them; he will despise it. Excommunicate; he will move the crowds and the church will be divided. But I do not want, you say, to be ejected and excommunicated and despised. But whoever has been cast out from the fellowship of the saints is most contemptuously despised. But let him have his own, you say; let us leave ours unharmed. He will not do it. You will say, it will be a holy persecution, but not necessarily brought upon us by God, nor imposed upon us. We can freely preach the truth, confess Christ freely and enjoy all the privileges of the church. One thing is missing: You want to reduce the Cinerites and lice to order by excommunication. But take care that we do not restore all the impious to freedom by that same means by which we wanted to bring them into order, so that they can take away from us all freedom of speaking, doing and confessing. Rather let us preach Christ holily, prophesy crimes, urge the magistrate to remember his duty wisely. Let us admonish a few times, unless they take stricter action against crimes, we will entrust excommunication to others. Let us exhort the pious to live piously, and let everyone prove himself worthy in the reception of the sacraments, especially when we see Judas receiving the sacrament of the body and blood of Christ; nay, what do I say of Judas, when I know that all the apostles received it, who after an hour or two defected from Christ, so that Peter denied himself to be a man he knew not. Let us therefore exhort the pious, let us exhort them again and again, let us gather our church in faith and doctrine. He who is of God has his seal. The wicked are going worse and worse day by day. The impious are excommunicated by God, and all those who believe in the preached Gospel shun and avoid our impious ones; they take care of themselves from them. But what of the pious and the apostles, that Judas communicates with them? He takes his own judgment.

seg.output:
What then is the need for many? I too can entrust the authority of excommunication to certain men, provided that this scheme brings glory to God in our city, or that we have done something better by this innovation, or that we might be able to more strongly oppose the impious and impiety than hitherto. For all things must be done by us for the edifying, and be done with circumspection, lest we cast the Church into the utmost danger. Baltazar Pacimontanus desired to introduce a new form of his city to the new Church, and scattered the whole Church. And what did Oecolampadius, a holy and everywhere learned man, promote among the Baselites? Is there less impiety among them? What did some once promote at St. Gall, to whom our most prudent, pious, and learned teacher Zwingli so much objected? Or what could we safely attempt in these turbulent times? Perhaps to give an opportunity to certain impious ones, that what they had long conceived, they might now be able to bring forth with our help? Take away from the Senate what you desire; entrust it to certain men. Who, however, will fear them? Let a cinder-man be called; he will despise it. Let him be excommunicated; he will stir up the crowd, and so the Church will be divided. But I do not wish, you say, for him to be rejected and excommunicated and despised. But he is most abjectly despised who is cast out of the fellowship of the saints. But let him have his own, you say, and leave ours untouched. He will not do it. "It will be a holy persecution," you say. But not necessarily brought about by us, not sent to us by God. For we can preach the truth freely, confess Christ freely, and enjoy all the privileges that the Church enjoys. One thing is lacking: you wish to reduce the cinder-men and lice into order by excommunication. But see to it that in this very means we do not restore all the impious to their liberty, which we wished to compel into order, that afterward they may take away from us all liberty of speaking, doing, and confessing. Rather let us preach Christ holily, accuse sins prophetically, urge the magistrates to remember their duty wisely. Let us sometimes threaten, unless they more severely take notice of the sins, that we shall now commit excommunication to others. Let us exhort the pious to live piously, and let each prove himself in the receiving of the sacraments, especially when we see Judas received the sacrament of the body and blood of Christ; nay, what do I say of Judas, when I know that all the apostles received it, who, after an hour or two, revolted from Christ, so that Peter denied holily that he knew not man. Let us, therefore, exhort the pious, let us again and again exhort them, let us collect our Church in faith and doctrine. He that is of God, hath his signet. The wicked are carried from bad to worse. The impious are excommunicated of God, and all who believe the preached Gospel avoid and shun our impious; they take heed to themselves from them. But what of the pious and apostles, that Judas communicates with them? He takes his judgment upon himself. The pious come in faith.
I wished to note these few things, Leo, most learned teacher and dearest brother to me. I wished not to answer every one, lest we brothers and allies should contend more hatefully. Nor is it as if you should think that I interpret anything to the worse part, nor do I bear anything hard. No intercessions are necessary with me. I love you, and venerate the learning and authority full of old age in you. I see and understand your mind, which is indeed holy and sincere.

seg.output: I wanted to briefly make a note, Leo, my most learned teacher and dearest brother. I did not want to respond to each one, so that brothers and theorists would not argue more hatefully. Nor should you think that I interpret anything in a worse part, nor do I bear anything with difficulty. No disputes are necessary with me. I love you and I revere your learning and your old age full of authority. I see and understand your mind, indeed it is holy and sincere. Therefore, I wanted to deal with this matter in more detail, so that I may be certain that you wanted to examine these matters, what I could achieve in the sacred: certainly, what you see and hear every day, little or certainly nothing. What could be more obvious? If we simply consider what excommunication is, namely the public protection of public honesty, and why it was instituted, namely, so that people would not sin more shamelessly in the church of Christ, and that it was given especially to the external church, and if we consider what flesh is, and that we are and remain people at all times of life, so that the spirit may be prompt, and finally that we may sooner hope for an undefiled church than possess it, then the matter will be easy. We will not be able to make the world any different than it was from the beginning. We would sooner establish a Novatian church than one perfectly complete in all respects.

seg.output:
I wanted to make a few notes, Leo, my most learned teacher and dearest brother. For I did not wish to reply to each one individually, lest my brothers and colleagues should contend more spitefully. Nor must you think that I interpret anything to the worse, nor do I bear anything grudgingly. No entreaties are necessary with me. I love you and revere your learning and your old age full of authority. I see and understand your mind, a holy and sincere one. Hence I wished to treat the matter in more detail, so that I might believe with certainty that you wished to be informed of what I can do in holy matters: certainly, what you see and hear day by day, little or certainly nothing. For what can be more clear? If we consider the matter simply, what excommunication is, namely, the public protection of public honour, and why it is instituted, namely, that men may not sin more impudently in the Church of Christ, and that it is given especially to the external Church, again, if we consider what flesh is, and that at all times of life we are and remain men, so that the spirit may be prompt, and finally, that we can hope sooner for an unpolluted Church than have it, the matter will be easy: we won't be able to change the world any other way than it was from the beginning. We could sooner establish a Novatian Church than one perfectly complete in all respects. The Lord, through Zwingli and you, has so advanced the Church of Zurich, that I believe with a good conscience that I have been a faithful servant to God, if I can retain it through his grace and your help, as it was instituted by you.
Farewell and keep me in your thoughts. March 15th 1532.
